oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ronnie McDowell Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Ronnie McDowell (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ronnie McDowell; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie invites the comparisons of Ronnie McDowell to Elvis Presley; McDowell reveals "The King is Gone" was the greatest publicity he had received -- (00:53) McDowell recalls the subject of his upcoming show being about Presley traveling through Texas -- (02:10) Collie and McDowell reflect on the public relations department of McDowell's new show, and both agree that the public relations department should be addressing country radio -- (04:56) McDowell recalls going to a radio station to promote his song about Presley -- (05:59) McDowell recalls the buzz his song received from WKDA and other stations -- (06:37) McDowell tells about how he had sold his home the same day he gained popularity -- (07:59) McDowell discusses how he was asked to perform more like Presley than himself -- (09:26) McDowell addresses how he saw Gene Autry and Roy Rogers live when he was young; McDowell says Hank Williams and Jimmie Rogers influenced his musical impersonations -- (10:20) McDowell's first guitar is revealed to be a Stella, and McDowell says the NBC chime was the first item he could play -- (11:36) McDowell recalls his first live performance was at a boy's birthday party; McDowell expresses his disinterest in school as a child -- (12:52) McDowell discusses how he was one of the few members of his family that went to college, and McDowell says his first professional work was in Vietnam -- (14:23) McDowell describes how Walter Brennan is his favorite television personality; McDowell expresses how he idolizes Clark Gable and that Gone With the Wind was his favorite Gable movie -- (17:02) McDowell discusses his discomfort with recording "Older Women," and how Jamie O'Hara convinced McDowell to record it with the Jordanaires -- (18:22) "Watching Girls Go By" is revealed to be a follow up to "Wandering Eyes" by McDowell -- (19:16) McDowell reflects on a time in 1979 when he was able to revive "Wandering Eyes" -- (20:59) "You're Gonna Ruin My Bad Reputation" is told by McDowell to be a song that was reworked by McDowell and Conway Twitty -- (21:57) McDowell reveals how he did not like the masculine message of "In a New York Minute;" McDowell reveals how his personal reservations affected his recording career -- (23:54) McDowell reflects on his creative process -- (24:22) "All Tied Up in Love" is revealed to be inspired from a car trip by McDowell -- (25:08) McDowell tells of how he met Twitty for the first time when he was eight years old -- (27:51) McDowell reflects on Twitty's insight and McDowell reveals the group of gentleman he idolizes -- (32:19) McDowell recalls how he wrote a lot of music in Vietnam and how he came to find his style -- (34:31) McDowell claims that he heard that Presley had died while driving, and McDowell says that inspired McDowell to drive to Memphis to see Presley -- (36:44) McDowell tells about how Lee Morgan had asked McDowell to do a tribute for Presley; that tribute song was "The King is Gone" -- (40:17) McDowell reflects on his career, and McDowell reflects on the pressures the industry place on him because of his Presley work -- (42:10) Collie and McDowell discuss how McDowell had agreed to perform on Elvis but did not want his name attached to the film -- (43:38) McDowell expresses how he had understood his aspirations at the age of six -- (44:34) McDowell jokes about showing Twitty "Personally" just to cut it himself -- (45:19) McDowell reflects on how "I Got a Million of Em" made number two on the charts, and McDowell explains the 'bridesmaid position' -- (45:57) McDowell reflects on how he restored vehicles for a time -- (48:22) McDowell praises the efforts of Karen McDowell, recalls how they met, and McDowell discusses his son's musical talents -- (51:56) McDowell says that It's Only Make Believe is his attempt to get away from the label he was given
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: McDowell, Ronnie; Collie, Biff;
